title: Combating Racisms
description: This course examines historical and contemporary practices, theories, principles, figures, and allies of anti-racism. Students will learn methods of communicating and pursuing anti-racism in culture, society, and in personal and professional interracial relationships. Coursework will immerse students in recognizing language, behaviours, institutions, and discourses that maintain white supremacies and further enable racist policies and practices in North America. Students will be challenged to apply course material to real issues of racisms in local contexts and communities.

title: Introduction to Anti-Racist Communication
description: This course surveys the rhetorical strategies of both more recent and historical civil rights and anti-racist activists. Students will use Black rhetorical theory and will examine work by international historical figures such as Franz Fanon, Aimé Césaire, Edouard Glissant, Albert Memmi, and Mohandas Gandhi, Frederick Douglas, WEB Dubois, Martin Luther King, Fannie Lou Hamer, Malcolm X, Angela Davis, Stokely Carmichael, Fred Hampton, Robert Hill, and Walter Rodney and such recent figures as Kimberle Crenshaw, Robyn Maynard, Brittney Cooper, Desmond Cole, Feminista Jones, Rinaldo Walcott, and Idil Abdillahi. The objective for students is to understand the evolution of liberatory, anti-racist rhetoric and the rhetorical successes and failures of key anti-racist activists.

title: Special Topics in Black Studies
description: A seminar course investigating special issues related to Black studies. Content may vary from year to year.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: Level at least 3A or students pursuing the Diploma in Black Studies or the Diploma in Fundamentals of Anti-Racist Communication

title: Contemporary African Literature and Film
description: Drawing on a wide range of genres that includes prose fiction, plays, popular fiction, and films/videos, this course will examine the development and growth of modern African literature and film (in English or in translation to English) from the late 1950s to the present and from different regions of the continent. Students will develop introductory knowledge of the varied historical and cultural contexts that shaped the rise and global circulation of contemporary African literature and film since the mid-twentieth century. Students will build their knowledge of the unique stylistic techniques that major writers and film-makers from Africa have used since the 1950s, and will increase their capacity for critical assessment of themes relating to colonization in Africa, cultural nationalism, politics and mis-governance, gender and identity politics, and globalization.
